awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Ca, Sr, Mg, and Fe isotope proxies to constrain redox and continental weathering during Ocean Anoxic Event 2
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid increases of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere can lead to changes in the global ocean, including increased acidification, lower oxygen, and significantly reduced plant and animal life.  This project’s scientists are interested in changes in ocean chemistry and global climate 94 million years ago when the atmosphere had up to 5 times more carbon dioxide than Earth’s present atmosphere, and the concentrations varied dramatically. The researchers are measuring isotopes of strontium, calcium, magnesium, and iron in rocks from the Eagle Ford Group in Texas that formed from an ancient seabed. The results are leading to a better understanding of the factors that led to and sustained that period of global warming, and they are revealing implications for present-day climate change. This research is aiding the career development of a Ph.D. student from an underrepresented group and an early career female scientist. A museum exhibit on climate and energy is being created to outreach to the public about this work.

The Late Cretaceous Ocean Anoxic Event 2 (OAE2) was a sustained period of high atmospheric carbon dioxide and consequent warming of the global climate. How global warming is related to volcanic activity, and the cascading effects on continental weathering and global ocean chemistry, remain open questions. A complete stratigraphic section through OAE2 from the Eagle Ford Group in Texas is being examined for Sr, Ca, Mg, and Fe isotopes.  Each of these element systems record distinct chemical information on the global ocean environment and on changing climate.  Numerical mass balance models based on the isotope data are being employed to constrain the inputs and outputs to the global ocean and the feedback between volcanic activity and continental weathering. Results are providing a framework for further examination of the causes of ocean anoxia and substantial climate change in the geological past, and are allowing a better understanding of the factors contributing to future climate change. Broader impacts of this project include mentoring and training students from underrepresented groups and public outreach about the links between climate and energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project applied a suite of novel, non-traditional isotope proxies to a complete stratigraphic section of the Late Cretaceous Ocean Anoxic Event 2 (OAE2), approximately 95 Ma, in the Eagle Ford Group in Texas. Investigating the Late Cretaceous OAE2 is an important window into understand how past warming events result in shifts in environmental conditions and key processes (such as weathering) because of the rise in atmospheric CO2 concentrations. The geochemical records collected (radiogenic and stable Sr, Ca, Mg, and Fe isotopes) help us to better understand the changes to Earth’s oceans as a result of CO2-induced climate change, with potential implications for long-term environmental response relevant for modern anthropogenic climate change. The Cretaceous Period was significantly warmer than today and therefore this case study provides a window into extreme responses. Specifically, these records can link volcanism and global climate change to changes in ocean environmental conditions as a consequence of changing continental weathering and marine oxygen content. Changes in these records are important for understanding the causes and consequences of climate change on an Earth with a much warmer climate than today.

Collection of radiogenic Sr, Fe isotope, calcium isotope, and stable strontium isotope data from the Iona-1 core that spans OAE 2 was completed and many of these data and their interpretations have been published. A major outcome of this research is the recognition that submarine volcanism can impart major isotope signatures of seawater (including strontium, chromium, and iron isotopes), despite the fact that this process is generally thought to be less impactful than other controls. Modeling constrained the increase in the continental weathering flux of Sr to 1.8 times, smaller than the estimate obtained from past studies of Ca and Li isotopes. This result reveals a more important role of hydrothermally derived sources of Sr, Cr, Fe and potentially, nutrients, than previously considered.

Thee results of this research also highlight the potential for records that are assumed to be the same across the ocean to vary between oceanic regions, particularly when waters were isolated due to the configuration of continents. Complementary studies on how isotope tracers are impacted by diagenesis in carbonate archives and compilations of redox proxies across geologic history, including in comparison to OAE 2, were also published. Last, the results of this project have broad implications for the interpretation of non-traditional paleoenvironmental isotope records, including the presentation of alternative interpretations of these data.

This project also developed a museum display in the Penn State College of Earth and Mineral Sciences Museum and Art Gallery titled “Cretaceous Oceans and Climate” as well as an accompanying lab for the Geobiology course that is taken by ~40 undergraduates every year. Under the leadership of a PhD student, labs were developed to introduce students to museum collections and science communication through museum education. The student received the Outstanding TA Award for her efforts. The exhibit is fully installed and seen by undergraduate, graduate, and alumni visitors. This project also included the mentorship of a Penn State B.S. Earth Science and Policy undergraduate student in geochemical modeling.
